I'd argue that evolution is one of the biggest cornerstones required for a rational atheism. If your only explanation from where all the various species of animals came from is that they all just appeared someday, it makes it a lot harder to deny the existence of a creator than if you have a theory that allows them to arise naturally through evolution.

Orangutans are actually really patient with their own infants. Even the big flanged males who'll fight each other on sight just let the babies do whatever. No idea what they'd do with a human infant, though, and Birute Galdikas, the Jane Goodall of orangutans, mentions an orangutan casually trying to murder her by pushing over a rotting tree, so you know, who knows, but out of any wild animal, I'd probably trust an orangutan most with an infant.

I think Marius Jacob is pretty cool: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marius_Jacob
In Toulon on July 3, 1899, Jacob pretended to suffer from hallucinations in order to avoid five years of reclusion. On April 19, 1900, he escaped from the asylum in Aix-en-Provence with the assistance of a male nurse and took refuge in Ste. There he organized a band of men, calling them "the workers of the night." The principles were simple: one does not kill, except to protect his life and his freedom from the police; one steals only from those considered to be social parasites - bosses, judges, soldiers, and the clergy - but never from the professions considered useful - architects, doctors, artists, etc.; finally, a percentage of the stolen money was to be invested into the anarchist cause. Jacob chose to avoid working with the idealistic anarchists and instead surrounded himself with criminals and fellow illegalists.

Worth noting: that concert pianist was Paul Wittgenstein, brother of the famous philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein. Paul had a bunch of pieces commissioned for him after losing his arm. He had an odd, to me, sense of ownership of the pieces, refusing to let anyone else play the works until after he died, since he had paid for them.

I'd like a return to Tropico 4-style campaigns, with easily replayable missions.
I'd also like game-long permanent choices. There aren't really any exclusionary choices right now. Building one factory doesn't prevent you from building another. I'd like to have you make choices that affect your island for the duration of the mission and that lock out other choices.
